update.description:
* Enable writing of non-track indexed data to genomedata archives

* Add support for writing based on track key and checking writes across supercontig boundaries

* Update NEWS on ability to write to archives

There is some concern about what the expected behavior is when writing across supercontigs. Currently if data written overlaps any region that isn't covered by a supercontig, an error is raised. This can be changed and might be a good subject of discussion.
update.title: Add feature to write data to archives

pull_request.title: Add feature to write data to archives

pullrequest.title: Add feature to write data to archives

content.raw:
So after much discussion there's a real consideration for including PyBedtools in the future but not for this particular pull request.

Regarding performance:

1. Using this method for writing should not be the primary method of writing. This is meant for small changes instead of having reload or recreate an archive. If you're loading in a large amount of data - load_data is the preferred method

2. When this method is used for writes, the amount of supercontigs under consideration is practically around 10 or so at max per write on a chromosome and in almost all cases should be much much smaller and realistically about 1. No algorithm is going to make this code significantly faster.

Regarding simplicity:

1. In general, adding dependencies for smaller features isn't the greatest idea especially since dealing with upstream changes can be frustrating in the long term. Granted, with Pybedtools this may not be as big of an issue but it does also require bedtools to be installed as well.

2. It would almost certainly make the code simpler and easier to maintain but for now the amount of code is still somewhat small in scope.

With all these points in mind it's still in the realm of possibility of using Pybedtools and introducing it as a dependency in the future. This is especially true when it comes to future features (like filtering out data) where it makes code significantly easier, cleaner and faster. If that happens then this code may be revisited for improving readability (and maybe performance).
content.html:
So after much discussion there's a real consideration for including PyBedtools in the future but not for this particular pull request.

Regarding performance:

  1. Using this method for writing should not be the primary method of writing. This is meant for small changes instead of having reload or recreate an archive. If you're loading in a large amount of data - load_data is the preferred method

  2. When this method is used for writes, the amount of supercontigs under consideration is practically around 10 or so at max per write on a chromosome and in almost all cases should be much much smaller and realistically about 1. No algorithm is going to make this code significantly faster.

Regarding simplicity:

  1. In general, adding dependencies for smaller features isn't the greatest idea especially since dealing with upstream changes can be frustrating in the long term. Granted, with Pybedtools this may not be as big of an issue but it does also require bedtools to be installed as well.

  2. It would almost certainly make the code simpler and easier to maintain but for now the amount of code is still somewhat small in scope.

With all these points in mind it's still in the realm of possibility of using Pybedtools and introducing it as a dependency in the future. This is especially true when it comes to future features (like filtering out data) where it makes code significantly easier, cleaner and faster. If that happens then this code may be revisited for improving readability (and maybe performance).

content.raw:
I think what you are saying is correct only if we can assume that most of the errors will occur at the start of the first checked chromosomes and I don't think we can make this assumption. Otherwise bedtools is going to be a lot more faster in all other cases I bet.

Can someone confirm that the method __setitem__ here is called for every new interval? If this is correct then I guess speed is going to be a issue as the number of new interval increases.
content.html:
I think what you are saying is correct only if we can assume that most of the errors will occur at the start of the first checked chromosomes and I don't think we can make this assumption. Otherwise bedtools is going to be a lot more faster in all other cases I bet.

Can someone confirm that the method setitem here is called for every new interval? If this is correct then I guess speed is going to be a issue as the number of new interval increases.

pull_request.title: Add feature to write data to archives

pullrequest.title: Add feature to write data to archives

content.raw:
It looks like the logic of the code here is very similar to what bedtools intersect does.

In fact we could use bedtools python api 'pybedtools' to simplify this code and avoid redundancy with existing code. The drawback is that this requires adding an extra dependency to bedtools and pybedtools to genomedata, which I don't think is a problem for bioinformaticians.

The idea would be to create two BedTool objects **before** opening the archive for writing (before calling setitem):

* object A contains the new coordinates that will be added to the archive
* object B contains coordinates of all the supercontigs

Then we can intersect objects A and B to find the intervals in A that do not overlap with B.
If the command returns any interval, it means that an interval in A overlaps with a gap so we can warn the user and stop here. 
Otherwise, we have the guarantee that all the intervals in A are within one or multiple supercontigs.

This approach has several additional advantages:
- we can extract all the verifications (checking for overlap) from the real simple logic of the __setitem__ method
- the more complex verification steps can be written in a different function which make it easier to test.

If you find this approach appealing, I think we can explore it further. For example, I am sure that we can use bedtools intersect efficiently to obtain a dict of (base_key -> supercontig).
content.html:
It looks like the logic of the code here is very similar to what bedtools intersect does.

In fact we could use bedtools python api 'pybedtools' to simplify this code and avoid redundancy with existing code. The drawback is that this requires adding an extra dependency to bedtools and pybedtools to genomedata, which I don't think is a problem for bioinformaticians.

The idea would be to create two BedTool objects before opening the archive for writing (before calling setitem):

  • object A contains the new coordinates that will be added to the archive
  • object B contains coordinates of all the supercontigs

Then we can intersect objects A and B to find the intervals in A that do not overlap with B. If the command returns any interval, it means that an interval in A overlaps with a gap so we can warn the user and stop here. Otherwise, we have the guarantee that all the intervals in A are within one or multiple supercontigs.

This approach has several additional advantages: - we can extract all the verifications (checking for overlap) from the real simple logic of the setitem method - the more complex verification steps can be written in a different function which make it easier to test.

If you find this approach appealing, I think we can explore it further. For example, I am sure that we can use bedtools intersect efficiently to obtain a dict of (base_key -> supercontig).

content.html:
Agree that it seems like at least some of the code could be made simpler by using pybedtools to perform the intersections. Would using pybedtools be faster than the current implementation?

@ericr86 is it possible for the list here to be a generator?

if any([(sorted_contigs[i].start - sorted_contigs[i-1].end) > 0  for i in range(1, num_supercontigs)])

Using bedtools intersect would require taking the full intersection. If we could have a complete generator expression above, then it would stop at the first instance of 'True' and might actually be faster since it does not guarantee parsing through the full list of sorted contigs.

content.raw:
I think this condition checks for overlapping supercontigs instead of gaps.

The condition:
(sorted_contigs[i-1].end - sorted_contigs[i].start) **>** 0

should be 
(sorted_contigs[i-1].end - sorted_contigs[i].start) **<** 0
content.html:
I think this condition checks for overlapping supercontigs instead of gaps.

The condition: (sorted_contigs[i-1].end - sorted_contigs[i].start) > 0

should be (sorted_contigs[i-1].end - sorted_contigs[i].start) < 0
